Award.AwardTitle: Wordbank: An Open Repository for Developmental Vocabulary Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Learning language is one of the most impressive and intriguing human accomplishments. Early language skills set the stage for later cognitive development and academic achievement. The goal of this project is to develop a powerful tool for researchers interested in typical and atypical language development to better understand young children's earliest language. This tool, called Wordbank, is a structured database of parent reports about children's vocabulary that combines tens of thousands of reports completed by parents whose children have participated in child development research. Wordbank will include data from research laboratories in dozens of countries, collected over many years and including many of the world's languages. This database will be useful for understanding generalizable trends across languages and cultures as well as exploring reasons that individual children might differ in their language development. Such a rich source of information will allow for novel insights that could not be discovered in smaller samples.

Wordbank will make use of the MacArthur-Bates Communicative Development Inventories (CDIs), a widely-used family of parent-report instruments that are designed for easy and inexpensive data-gathering about children's early language acquisition. Wordbank will archive CDI data across languages and labs in an item-by-child format relational database. Built on open-source analytic tools, the site will host in-depth exploratory visualizations and facilitate the productive reuse of data. In addition to an interactive interface for exploration, the website will also allow researchers to connect directly to the underlying database. The result will be a resource that enables new discoveries about early language across a variety of disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Children's early language learning is one of the most important issues in cognitive science. The current project aimed to bring larger datasets together to address open research questions regarding early language. In particular, Wordbank (http://wordbank.stanford.edu) – the focus of our work in this project - is a website for archiving parent-reported vocabulary from young children, using archival data from the MacArthur-Bates Communicative Development Inventory. The goals of the project were:

1) to develop the Wordbank website to support interaction and queries of the database,

2) to gather and enter data into the database from labs around the world, and

3) to perform novel analyses of the data in the database so as to address practically and theoretically important questions about vocabulary development.

Over the past three years, we have expanded the Wordbank site to include data from more than 75,000 children and more than 25 languages. This expansion makes it without question the biggest and most diverse dataset of children's early language outcomes. Further, the website now supports a number of interactive visualizations so that researchers, parents, and educators can engage directly with the data.

We have performed a large number of analyses of the data from this database, replicating essentially all of the previous influential analyses of early language data of this type in an open, cross-linguistic, and extensible manner. This work effectively centralizes insights from the last 20-30 years of study and providing a basis for future work to build on. Topics of these analyses include the relationship between language and demographics like gender and socioeconomic status; the relationship between children's early grammar and their word learning; and the bias for nouns in children's early language (among others). Parent report is only one tool in the researcher's toolkit, but it is a great starting point for finding out more about a particular aspect of child language before doing more systematic studies. To facilitate this goal, we are currently preparing a reference monograph reporting the full body of cross-linguistic research using Wordbank. 

Beyond its relevance as an important topic for basic research, a better understanding of early language learning is an important applied issue. Children with stronger early language skills achieve better academic success when they enter formal education. The Wordbank project facilitates an understanding of the factors that contribute to early language learning, providing insights that can easily translated into both intervention and evaluation.
